text:
GARY STEPHANOLPOULOS:
Oftentimes,

I like to ask my
students if they

think that a cell is more
complex compared to a 747,
let's say.

And of course, we do not know
the answer to this question,

but the answers I get from
them, they are about 3 to 1
in favor of a cell.

The difference, of course,
between a cell and the 747

is that we have built the
747 so we know how it works,

and if we don't
understand a part of it,

then we can just go there,
dissect it, and find out what's
going on inside that system.

We could not do that with
cells until very recently.

This has all changed
in recent times because

of the unprecedented ability
that we are developing

to go inside the
cell and measure

a lot of different
components of the cell.

And of course, as a
result of that capability,

we can now ask the question
how all of these pieces

come together and how
do they work together

to give us the functions of the
cell and the cell in connection

with the bigger organism
that we try to analyze.

In the context of
biotechnology, the two organisms

that we are studying
at this time

are Escherichia coli and
the photosynthetic bacterium
in Synechocystis.

In E. coli, we try to
understand the mechanisms that

allow these cells to accumulate
large amounts of lycopene

and beta carotene, and then, as
a result of that understanding,

to make the cells produce
more of that useful chemical.

One technique that's being
used to allow us to visualize

the activity of genes
such as these genes

is to couple the expression
of these genes with a marker,

such as green
fluorescent protein,

and if you see a large
amount of fluorescence,

that means that there is a
high degree of expression

of the gene that is involved
in the synthesis of lycopene.

For the case of
Synechocystis, Synechocystis
is a photosynthetic bacterium.

It has the ability to fix carbon
dioxide from the atmosphere,

and it also has the capability
to convert that carbon

dioxide into a number of
different valuable products.

One of these products
is a biopolymer.

And what we try to do in the
lab is basically two things.

One, to accelerate the rate
of fixation of carbon dioxide,

and the other, two, accelerate
the conversion of that fixed
carbon dioxide into biopolymer.

Some practical applications that
may come out of this research

are the production of
biodegradable polymers.

These are polymers
which will degrade in

the environment naturally,
leaving no trace behind them.

On top of all of
that, of course,

we are reducing the
amount of carbon dioxide
in the atmosphere.

So all of these products
come free from carbon dioxide

that we would like to
remove in the first place.

So the environmental impact
is double in this regard.

One characteristic of this area
is the intense collaboration

of scientists from
different backgrounds
and with different interests.

Because a lot of activity is
taking place at the interfaces

between engineering
and life sciences,

this cannot be done in
a single laboratory,

and it is important to get
many people together in order
to answer a particular question.
